title: Domain 2.4: Given a scenario, analyze indicators of malicious activity.
content:
ü¶† Malware Attacks

  • Ransomware: Encrypts files and demands payment.
  • Trojan: Disguised as legit software, performs malicious tasks.
  • Worm: Spreads automatically without user interaction.
  • Spyware: Secretly monitors activity, captures data.
  • Bloatware: Pre-installed, slows systems or hides threats.
  • Virus: Attaches to files, spreads when executed.
  • Keylogger: Records keystrokes to steal sensitive data.
  • Logic bomb: Triggers under specific conditions.
  • Rootkit: Hides presence, grants attacker control.

ü•ä Physical Attacks

  • Brute force: Tries many credentials until one works.
  • RFID cloning: Duplicates RFID cards/devices.
  • Environmental: Threats like fire, flood, or power loss.

üåê Network Attacks

  • DDoS: Floods target with traffic to disrupt service.
  • Amplified: Small requests = big response flood.
  • Reflected: Attack traffic bounced via third-party servers.
  • DNS attacks: Redirects, poisons, or disrupts DNS.
  • Wireless attacks: Includes rogue APs, deauth, weak encryption.
  • On-Path: Intercepts and alters communication.
  • Credential Replay: Reuses stolen credentials.
  • Malicious Code: Injected code to compromise systems.

üíª Application Attacks

  • Injection: Inserts code to manipulate backend.
  • Buffer overflow: Overwrites memory to execute code.
  • Replay: Captures and reuses valid sessions.
  • Privilege escalation: Gains higher access rights.
  • Forgery: Fakes tokens/cookies to impersonate.
  • Directory traversal: Accesses restricted files via path manipulation.

üîê Cryptographic Attacks

  • Downgrade attack: Forces use of weak encryption.
  • Collision attack: Two inputs = same hash.
  • Birthday attack: Uses probability to find hash matches.

üîë Password Attacks

  • Password spraying: Tries common passwords across many accounts.
  • Brute force: Tries all possible combinations.

üö® Indicators of Malicious Activity

  • Account lockout: Many failed logins‚Äîbrute force possible.
  • Concurrent session usage: Same account in multiple places.
  • Blocked content: User tries to access restricted resources.
  • Impossible travel: Logins from far apart in short time.
  • Resource consumption: High CPU/network‚Äîmaybe malware.
  • Resource inaccessibility: Systems suddenly unavailable.
  • Out-of-cycle logging: Logs at unusual times‚Äîpossible tampering.
  • Published indicators: Match known attack signatures.
  • Missing logs: Logs deleted or manipulated to cover tracks.
